Award.AwardTitle: Interaction of Air, Sea Ice, and Ocean Around Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Weather observation networks of key observables such as surface air pressure (SAP) and surface air temperature (SAT) are the foundation of numerical weather prediction (NWP) and also of climate modeling. These observations in the Southern Ocean and the sea-ice around the Antarctic continent remain some of the most poorly observed regions of the planet. This proposal offers to extend measurement capabilities (SAP, SAT - air and sea), sea ice motion and ocean temperature to 200 m depth) through the deployment of a number of drifting buoys, based on those routinely used in the Arctic ice buoy program. As well as their potential use in NWP (e.g. AMPS, used operationally in USAP), the collected data will be compared to existing reanalysis fields such as the NCEP/NCAR and ECMWF efforts. and made avaialble to interested USAP researchers.

Target areas will include the Amundsen and Ross Sea regions, especially polynas, which may serve to increase operational forecast skill in the McMurdo area. Other impacts of the proposed research include public outreach through existing educational awareness programs at the lead institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observations of surface air pressure (SAP) and surface air temperature (SAT) provide the foundation of our ability to forecast weather and ice conditions, and our ability to understand the earth’s climate and climate change. These basic variables are monitored through out the globe by weather stations on land, moored buoys along the coast, and drifting buoys in most of the world’s oceans. However, the Southern Ocean and sea ice around Antarctica continue to be one of the least sampled areas of the planet. This lack of observations around Antarctica hinders our ability to accurately predict weather (Bromwich and Cassano, 2001), and limits our ability to document the climate of Antarctica (e.g. Hines et al., 2000; Bromwich and Fogt, 2004; Bromwich et al., 2007)

Through this grant, we deployed a network of 85 drifting buoys in the Southern Ocean, which measure sea level pressure, surface temperature (air and sea), sea ice motion, and ocean temperatures down to 60 m from 2012–2015 (Fig. 1). These observations were: 1.) collected and quality controlled; 2.) analyzed to produce hourly time series of SAP, SAT, ocean temperature and sea ice motion; 3) contributed to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC) Global Telecommunications System (GTS) for operation weather and ice forecasting; and 4.) provided to the research community through our web servers. Our research has focused on assessing the gridded fields of SAP from numerical models, such as the National Center for Environmental Prediction (NCEP), and National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) reanalyses, and satellite retrievals of sea ice motion. Our analyses SAP show high correlations (r >= 0.95) between the numerical models estimates and the observations. And in Figure. 2, we show a new analyses of sea ice trajectories retrieved from sequential QuikSCAT satellite images validated using the drift of buoys on sea ice in the Southern Ocean. These in situ observations from buoys provide critical atmospheric, ice, and upper ocean hydrographic measurements that have a myriad of uses, and cannot be obtained by other means.

The Scientists on this grant have a multi-faceted outreach program, which engages students, and the popular press to share science with the public. For example, Dr. Rigor was a Science Advisor for the popular British Broadcasting Series, Frozen Planet. Drs. Steele and Rigor meet the public at the annual Polar Science Weekend that they helped develop at Seattle’s Pacific Science Center (PSC, the largest museum in the northwest), and are also featured semi-annually in their “Portal To Current Research” exhibit. During the period of this grant, Dr. Rigor was on the committees of graduate students, Cynthia Travers and Caroline Bell, and is the Primary Advisor for Melinda Webster who will defend her dissertation in 2016.
